entry.title: Invoice Validation with SAP Document Information Extraction API & Python
entry.content:
Invoices are essential, but validating them manually can be tedious and error-prone. In this blog post, we’ll walk through a Python-based workflow that leverages SAP’s Document Information Extraction (DOX) API to extract invoice data and intelligently compare it against field records. The goal? Validate invoices and highlight discrepancies—all in one go.

Supported document types for the SAP Document Information Extraction Service include supplier invoice, purchase order, payment advice, and business cards. More to come in the roadmap.

This blog post builds on an excellent introductory guide by Joni – here – which covers getting started with SAP DOX API and testing it via Swagger. Here, we introduce Python logic, with Python modelling doing the heavy lifting of:

  • OCR-based document post and extraction (via SAP DOX API)
  • Confidence scoring and validation of key fields
  • Automatic detection and reporting of mismatches

TL;DR: Automate invoice data extraction and validation using SAP DOX API and Python. OCR your PDFs, validate against expected fields with confidence scoring, and flag mismatches—all in one streamlined Python pipeline.

This guide is for: SAP BTP developers, automation engineers, finance teams exploring DOX integration, or anyone dealing with high-volume invoice processing.

Step 1: Authentication with SAP BTP

First, we authenticate against SAP BTP using OAuth 2.0 to retrieve an access token.
Update <TENANT> to your SAP BTP tenant name.

The Bearer Token is required for all subsequent API calls to the DOX endpoint.

import requests
import json
 
client_id = ""
client_secret = ""
oauth_url = "https://<TENANT>.authentication.ap10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token?grant_type=client_credentials"
 
# Get access token
def get_access_token():
    token_response = requests.post(
        oauth_url,
        data={
            "grant_type": "client_credentials",
            "client_id": client_id,
            "client_secret": client_secret,
        },
        headers={
            "Content-Type": "application/x-www-form-urlencoded"
        }
    )
    
    if token_response.status_code == 200:
        return token_response.json().get("access_token")
    else:
        raise Exception(f"Failed to get token: {token_response.status_code} - {token_response.text}")

Step 2: Submitting an Invoice PDF for Document Information Extraction

Next, we upload a sample invoice PDF (in this case, Thai_Invoice_with_TH_date.pdf) to the DOX API. The POST/document/jobs endpoint performs a document submission (e.g a pdf, png or jpeg file) for asynchronous processing. If successful, the API returns a job ID which we use to track and fetch the results. This ID can be used with other endpoints, including GET/document/jobs/{id} and DELETE/document/jobs/{id}.

Sample Invoice:

import requests

url = "https://<TENANT>.ap10.doc.cloud.sap/document-information-extraction/v1/document/jobs"
access_token = get_access_token()
file_path = "Thai_Invoice_with_TH_date.pdf"

headers = {
    "Authorization": f"Bearer {access_token}",
    "accept": "application/json"
}

# simulate -F flags in curl
files = {
    'file': (file_path, open(file_path, 'rb'), 'application/pdf'),
    'options': (
        None,
        '''{
            "schemaName": "SAP_invoice_schema",
            "clientId": "c_00",
            "documentType": "invoice",
            "receivedDate": "2020-02-17",
            "enrichment": {
                "sender": {
                    "top": 5,
                    "type": "businessEntity",
                    "subtype": "supplier"
                }
            }
        }''',
        'application/json'
    )
}

response = requests.post(url, headers=headers, files=files)

if response.status_code in [200, 201]:
    print("Document submitted successfully!")
    print("ID:", response.json().get("id"))
else:
    print("Submission failed")
    print("Status Code:", response.status_code)
    print("Response:", response.text)

Step 3: Retrieving Extracted Data

Using the job ID, we retrieve the results. Replace {id} with the ID in the previous output. From the SAP Document Information Extraction interface, you’ll also see your extracted fields formatted.

The extracted fields (like receiver address, receiver name, document date, and net amount) are returned with confidence scores, allowing us to evaluate the reliability of each extracted field.

You get the actual confidence scores via the DOX API instead of an extraction confidence range on the interface.

url = f"https://<TENANT>.ap10.doc.cloud.sap/document-information-
extraction/v1/document/jobs/{ID}"
response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)

if response.status_code == 200:
    data = response.json()
    fields = data.get("extraction", {}).get("headerFields", [])

    if not fields:
        print("No header fields extracted.")
    else:
        print("Extracted Fields:")
        for field in fields:
            print(f"- {field['name']}: {field['value']} (confidence: {round(field['confidence'], 2)})")
else:
    print("Failed to retrieve job data")
    print("Status:", response.status_code)
    print("Response:", response.text)

Step 4: Document Confidence Scoring and Mandatory Field Check

We define a list of mandatory fields and set a minimum confidence threshold (e.g., 70%).

The Document Confidence Score is reflected at the end of the output after checking for matching and missing fields.

min_confidence = 0.7  # threshold to flag low-match fields

mandatory_fields = {
    "receiverName": "Buyer Name",
    "receiverAddress": "Buyer Address",
    "documentDate": "Date Issued",
    "documentNumber": "Invoice Number",
    "currencyCode": "Currency",
    "taxAmount": "VAT Value",
    "senderAddress": "Company Address",
    "senderName": "Company Name",
    "taxId": "Tax ID"
}

if response.status_code == 200:
    data = response.json()
    fields = data.get("extraction", {}).get("headerFields", [])
    
    # Convert extracted fields into a dictionary: name => field
    extracted = {f["name"]: f for f in fields}
    
    total_score = 0
    max_score = len(mandatory_fields)
    low_match_flags = []

    print("Mandatory Field Check:\n")

    for key, label in mandatory_fields.items():
        field = extracted.get(key)
        if field:
            total_score += 1  # Presence of field
            print(f"{label} ({key}): {field['value']}") 
        else:
            print(f"{label} ({key}): MISSING")

    print("\nResult Summary:")
    print(f"Fields Found: {total_score}/{max_score}")
    
    if total_score < max_score:
        print("\nLow Match Fields:")
        # Check for missing fields and flag low match
        for key, label in mandatory_fields.items():
            if key not in extracted:
                print(f" - {label} ({key})")

    document_confidence_score = round((total_score / max_score) * 100, 2)
    print(f"\nDocument Confidence Score: {document_confidence_score}%")

else:
    print("Failed to fetch job results.")
    print(f"Status Code: {response.status_code}")
    print(f"Response: {response.text}")

Future Expansion

For integration and tracking – you’ll want your enterprise system as part of the Document Information Extraction process. While keeping all validation logic in Python, you can expand the case with fuzzy matching, error handling, and real databases, including SAP S/4HANA or SAP Build Process Automation:

  1. Pull real data dynamically
  2. Push results (e.g. approved/rejected invoices)
  3. Trigger workflows (emails, dashboards, auto-approval/review flagging etc.)
  4. Store validated invoice results in your backend
  5. Log confidence scores, mismatches, timestamps

All in all, this blog post provides a preliminary look into:

  • Invoice document posting and extraction with the SAP DOX API
  • Invoice validation
  • Confidence scoring

If you process high volumes of invoices, SAP Document Information Extraction can help you save countless hours and reduce errors.

Leave your thoughts or questions in the comment section below!

entry.title: Artificial Intelligence(AI) & Machine Learning(ML) in SAP S/4HANA:Transforming Enterprise Operations
entry.content:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) in SAP S/4HANA: Transforming Enterprise Operations

After working in SAP SD for over 15 years, I have seen the module evolve from being purely transactional to becoming a key driver of customer experience and revenue performance. What excites me about AI now is how it can finally unlock the next level moving from reactive order processing to intelligent, predictive selling.

AI can help us optimize pricing in real time, anticipate customer needs based on buying patterns, and even automate complex order management scenarios. It’s no longer just about automating tasks it’s about transforming how sales and distribution contribute to the business.

With AI, I see huge potential to reduce order errors, improve delivery commitments, and give sales teams the insights they need right when they need them. It’s the kind of evolution that brings together both efficiency and strategy. And honestly, after a decade and a half in this space, that’s the kind of shift that gets me genuinely excited.

Let’s talk about what is Artificial intelligence, Machine learning in simple term.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) is the computers or machines being made to think and decide like humans. It's about putting machines in a position where they can do things that typically need to be done by human intelligence — like interpreting language, identifying pictures, solving mysteries, or making decisions.

Machine Learning (ML) is either a sub-domain (or subset) of AI. It's the way that we're teaching machines to get intelligent independently. We're not writing each of the rules but giving them many data and that machine would observe patterns over this data. After that, whenever it could be able to independently make a choice or forecast.

Basic example:

If AI has to do something like instructing a robot about recognizing fruits

So ML is kind of like demonstrating the robot pictures of apples, bananas, and oranges — and letting it learn what each of them looks like, instead of explaining to it all the rules

Introduction of AI and ML in SAP

SAP S/4HANA, the cutting-edge ERP suite, is transforming the way businesses operate by incorporating advanced technologies like Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML). These innovations boost automation, refine decision-making, and maintain data integrity across a variety of industries. In this blog, we’ll dive into how AI and ML are woven into SAP S/4HANA and explore their practical applications in the real world. 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) & Machine Learning (ML) in SAP S/4HANA

SAP S/4HANA leverages AI and ML to automate processes, reduce manual work, and provide predictive insights. Below are some key functionalities:

Sales & Customer Experience

  1. Automated Sales Order Processing: AI-powered chatbots process customer inquiries and create sales orders automatically, improving response times.

2. Leverage Joule

Joule is capable of creating sales orders in both the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and the Public Edition. It’s also a handy tool for managing various aspects of sales orders, including: -

  • Creating sales orders based on other documents: Joule can generate new sales orders by referencing existing sales orders, quotes, or contracts.
  • Generating sales order requests: It can assist users in crafting sales order requests by pulling information from unstructured data like PDFs or images.
  • Modifying sales order fields: Users can easily update fields at both the header and item levels with Joule.
  • Addressing sales order fulfilment issues: It’s equipped to help users tackle any problems related to fulfilling sales orders.
  • Navigating to relevant apps: Joule can direct users to specific applications within SAP S/4HANA Cloud, such as the "Track Sales Orders" app.
  • Retrieving sales order information: It can deliver summaries and detailed insights about sales orders, including document flow and pricing condition

 3. AI-Based Sales Order Autocompletion:

Functionality: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition offers AI-driven autocompletion, which uses historical data and machine learning to provide intelligent recommendations for completing sales order data. 

Example: The system can suggest the correct shipping address, payment terms, or material details based on past orders with similar characteristics. 

SAP Fiori App: The "Monitor Recommendations for Sales Document Completion" app provides a central entry point to view incomplete sales orders and corresponding data field recommendations. 

4. Importing Sales Orders from Excel Spreadsheets:

Functionality: You can use the SAP Fiori app "Import Sales Orders" to batch-create sales orders directly from Excel files. 

Process:

    • Upload the Excel file containing the sales order data. 
    • The system automatically creates sales order requests and populates the data. 
    • You can then simulate or create the sales order. 

SAP BTP Use Case:  SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) can be used to automate sales order creation from Excel files, leveraging robotic process automation (RPA) to extract data from Excel and create sales order documents in SAP S/4HANA. 

5. Automating Sales Order Creation from Unstructured Data:

Functionality: You can use SAP Build Process Automation to create an RPA bot to automate the processing of sales order requests received in the form of unstructured files like PDFs, images, etc

 

 Process:

    • The bot scans emails for keywords in the subject line. 
    • It extracts attachments from the emails and uploads them to the "Create Sales Orders - Automatic Extraction" app. 
    • The app creates sales order requests and uploads the email attachments to a document information extraction service. 
    • The service extracts relevant information from the email attachments. 

6. SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, duplicate detection

Sales agents can leverage the feature that performs a check, comparing the configured fields with the list of existing accounts within the system. As an administrator, they can configure the duplicate check for accounts. Once configured, any new account that is created is checked against the configured fields and the result displays a list of the existing accounts with a confidence score, which enables sales agents to take a decision whether or not to proceed with the account creation.

Benefits

    • Prevent from creating more duplicate records, improving data accuracy
    • Ensure a cleaner database for operations and sales forecasts

entry.title: Data Attribute Recommendation: 12-Month Support Window for New and Existing Deployments
entry.content:
UPDATE: This change (12-month support window for new and existing deployments) is still under discussion with the stakeholders of Data Attribute Recommendation. The September 1st deadline should be updated once an agreement is reached.

As of September 1st, 2025, Data Attribute Recommendation will only support the deployment of trained models that are less than 12 months old. Additionally, any existing deployments that are more than 12 months old will be retired automatically, ensuring that only up-to-date, high-quality models remain active. 

 

Why is this change being introduced?  

The overall goal is to strengthen the security and enhance the machine learning lifecycle of the service. To achieve this, we recommend that you, as a user of Data Attribute Recommendation, retrain and redeploy your models on a regular basis. This brings numerous benefits, including the following:  

  • Security: Keeping all your deployments up to date makes sure that they constantly benefit from the security patches and fixes delivered with every release of the service. 
  • Data Drift: Over time, the statistical properties of the data received by the model may change. This phenomenon is known as data drift and can cause the model's performance to degrade. Regular retraining helps the model adapt to these data changes. 
  • Concept Drift: This is similar to data drift, but instead of the data changing, the relationship between the input data and the target variable(s) changes. Regular retraining helps the model capture these new relationships. 
  • Improved Data Availability: Over time, more data usually becomes available. Training a new model with this additional data can improve its accuracy and robustness. 
  • Model Improvements: Machine learning is a rapidly evolving field where new algorithms, architectures, and techniques are constantly being developed. Performance, efficiency, and scalability improvements are regularly included in the Data Attribute Recommendation scenarios. Therefore, retraining regularly allows you to take full advantage of these continuous enhancements. 
  • Error Correction: Regular retraining allows you to correct any errors or biases that were present in the initial training data or model.  

Retraining and redeploying models on a regular basis is a best practice that ensures your machine learning systems remain robust, relevant, and aligned with your organization’s strategic goals and operational requirements.  

 

How to keep your models up to date in Data Attribute Recommendation  

  • Ensure the latest data is uploaded to the service. 
  • Train a new model on the data: If you want to do this while the old model is still running, you must choose a different model name.  
  • Deploy the newly trained model. 
  • Update the URL that you send your inference requests to. They should now go to the newly trained model. 
  • Undeploy the old model. 

 To complete these steps, we recommend that you consult our documentation: AI API Reference.

entry.title: SAP -Generative AI
entry.content: In today’s fast-evolving digital economy, businesses are increasingly seeking ways to enhance productivity, improve decision-making, and deliver personalized experiences. Artificial Intelligence (AI) has emerged as a cornerstone in this transformation, and SAP is at the forefront, embedding AI directly into its business processes through SAP Business AI.

entry.title: Generative AI with SAP – Introduction to SAP Business AI
entry.content:
In today’s fast-evolving digital economy, businesses are increasingly seeking ways to enhance productivity, improve decision-making, and deliver personalized experiences. Artificial Intelligence (AI) has emerged as a cornerstone in this transformation, and SAP is at the forefront, embedding AI directly into its business processes through SAP Business AI.

This blog serves as an introduction to SAP Business AI, with a focus on Generative AI and its integration into the SAP ecosystem.

 

What Is SAP Business AI?

SAP Business AI is SAP’s portfolio of AI technologies and services embedded across its applications and platforms. Unlike generic AI platforms, SAP Business AI is enterprise-ready, context-aware, and responsible by design, tailored to help businesses become more intelligent and agile.

Key components of SAP Business AI include:

1.Embedded AI capabilities in SAP applications (e.g., SAP S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Customer Experience)

2.Industry-specific AI scenario

  1. Business-centric AI models trained on anonymized and consented SAP data
  2. Tools for developing, deploying, and managing AI

 

What Is Generative AI?

Generative AI refers to AI systems capable of generating new content, such as text, images, code, and even designs. It leverages large language models (LLMs) and transformers to understand and produce human-like outputs based on prompts.

In a business context, Generative AI opens up possibilities for:

  1. Automating document creation (e.g., invoices, job descriptions)
  2. Summarizing reports and meeting notes
  3. Writing personalized marketing content
  4. Assisting in coding and debugging
  5. Enhancing customer service with intelligent chatbots

 

Generative AI in SAP Business AI

SAP integrates Generative AI within its solutions through a responsible and enterprise-focused approach.

  1. SAP Joule – Your AI Copilot

SAP introduced Joule; a natural language copilot embedded across SAP cloud applications. Joule helps users:

  1. Retrieve business insights in real time
  2. Automate tasks with simple prompts
  3. Interact conversationally with enterprise data

For example, a procurement officer can ask:
What are the top 5 vendors based on last quarter’s delivery performance?
Joule delivers a contextual, data-driven answer instantly.

  1. Partnering with Leading LLM Providers

SAP collaborates with OpenAI, Anthropic, and Google Cloud Vertex AI to integrate advanced LLMs into its applications, while maintaining enterprise-grade data privacy and security.

  1. SAP AI Core and AI Launchpad

For developers, SAP AI Core provides infrastructure to manage and deploy AI models, including Generative AI. SAP AI Launchpad offers tools to monitor and govern these models responsibly.

 

Use Cases of Generative AI in SAP

Here are some real-world examples of how Generative AI is used across SAP solutions:

AreaUse Case
HR (SuccessFactors)Auto-generate job descriptions based on role requirements
Finance (S/4HANA)Summarize financial reports and detect anomalies
Customer ServiceGenerate dynamic responses in chatbots
ProcurementDraft vendor emails and contracts
Sales & MarketingCreate personalized campaign content

Responsible AI with SAP

SAP emphasizes ethical AI use, focusing on:

  1. Transparency: Clearly informing users when AI is used
  2. Privacy: Ensuring data is handled securely and anonymized
  3. Fairness: Avoiding bias in model training and outputs

With its AI Ethics Policy and governance frameworks, SAP is committed to delivering AI that customers can trust.

 

Getting Started

To explore SAP Business AI:

  1. Try out Joule in your SAP applications
  2. Explore the SAP AI Core and Launchpad on SAP BTP
  3. Visit the SAP Discovery Center for Generative AI use cases
  4. Join the SAP Community to connect with AI experts and peers

Generative AI is more than a buzzword - it’s a powerful tool driving intelligent automation and innovation across industries. With SAP Business AI, organizations can unlock the value of AI within familiar business processes, responsibly and securely.

Stay tuned for deep dives into specific use cases, technical integrations, and customer success stories in future posts.

 

What Is Joule?

Imagine having a trusted AI companion by your side, ready to assist and enhance your daily operations using the power of natural language and generative capabilities across SAP’s cloud portfolio that’s Joule.

Joule is:

  1. An advanced, generative AI copilot embedded throughout SAP’s cloud enterprise portfolio
  2. Designed to deliver proactive and contextualized insights from SAP applications and third-party sources
  3. Built to help people get work done faster and drive better business outcomes in a secure, compliant way

 

How Will Customers Use Joule?

Joule quickly sorts through and contextualizes data from multiple systems to surface smarter insights. It will be embedded across applications including HR, finance, supply chain, procurement, and customer experience, and integrated into SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

Users can ask questions or present problems in plain language and receive intelligent, context-aware answers.

For example:

  1. A manufacturer asks Joule about sales performance.
  2. Joule identifies underperforming regions, links it to supply chain data, and suggests fixes.
  3. In HR, it can write inclusive job descriptions and suggest interview questions.

 

Some Important Facts About Joule

Integration with SAP Applications:
Joule provides a conversational UI integrated with SAP apps, using SAP Fiori-compliant components.

Enterprise-Readiness:
Out-of-the-box integration with SAP backend systems, aligned with AI ethics, GDPR, and privacy controls. Joule is SOC-II compliant.

Automatic Updates:
Joule is continuously updated to include new capabilities and improvements.

 

How to Stay Updated on Joule

Explore these resources:

  1. SAP Joule product page
  2. SAP Community for Joule updates
  3. SAP Discovery Center for use cases

 

Joule in Procurement – Empowering Smart, AI-Driven Decisions

Procurement is a strategic function where speed, accuracy, and insight are critical. Joule brings transformative capabilities to procurement by enabling:

  1. Conversational access to enterprise data
  2. Automation of repetitive tasks
  3. Enhanced decision-making

Real-Time Spend Analysis

Instead of digging through reports, simply ask -
"What was our total spend on IT hardware in Q1 across all regions?"
Joule retrieves and visualizes the data instantly.

Supplier Evaluation

Ask:
Which suppliers had the highest late delivery rate last quarter?
Joule evaluates performance using embedded analytics and ML.

RFQ and Email Drafting

Joule can:

  1. Draft RFQs
  2. Create follow-up emails
  3. Propose contract language

Example:
Draft an RFQ for 500 ergonomic office chairs with delivery in two weeks.

Workflow Acceleration

Speed up approvals:

  1. Show PRs needing my approval
  2. Approve all low-risk PRs below $5,000

Compliance & Risk Detection

Stay audit-ready:
Which POs are missing documentation?
Joule flags issues proactively.

 

Why It Matters

In procurement, Joule enables:

  1. Faster decision-making
  2. Improved collaboration
  3. Proactive risk mitigation
  4. Higher operational efficiency

Joule doesn’t replace professionals — it amplifies them.

Coming soon: Expanded capabilities across the entire procurement lifecycle — from sourcing to supplier collaboration — all within the trusted SAP ecosystem.

 

https://www.sap.com/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant.html

 

Thankyou...

entry.title: 7 Groundbreaking AI Announcements at SAP Sapphire 2025 You Shouldn’t Miss
entry.content:
At SAP Sapphire 2025, the spotlight was firmly on Artificial Intelligence — not as a future ambition, but as the new operational core of enterprise software. SAP unveiled a suite of innovations designed to make AI tangible, scalable, and deeply integrated into business processes.

Here’s a quick rundown of the 7 most exciting AI announcements you need to know.

1. Joule Is Now Omnipresent

SAP’s AI copilot, Joule, has evolved. It’s now context-aware, ever-present, and embedded across both SAP and non-SAP tools. With its new Action Bar, Joule can proactively recommend actions and automate tasks based on user behavior. It’s your AI assistant — wherever you work.

The biggest upgrade? A Perplexity AI partnership, allowing Joule to bring in real-time, verified insights from the public web to enhance its enterprise answers.

2. Agentic AI Goes Mainstream

SAP is rolling out an ecosystem of pre-built AI agents. These aren’t just tools — they’re task-oriented mini AIs built to manage workflows across HR, supply chain, finance, and sales. Examples include:

  • Shop Floor Supervisor Agent

  • Expense Validation Agent

  • Quote Creation & Catalog Optimization Agents

They can now even collaborate across systems, thanks to the new Agent2Agent protocol developed with Google.

3. AI Agent Hub + LeanIX Integration

Managing AI agents just got easier with the new AI Agent Hub and its connection to SAP LeanIX. This lets enterprises map each agent to a specific business process or capability — bringing structure and governance to your AI operations.

4. SAP AI Foundation Becomes the OS for AI

The newly launched SAP AI Foundation is like an operating system for enterprise AI. It includes:

  • AI Agent Runtime

  • Prompt Optimizer (make your prompts smarter & model-agnostic)

  • Joule Studio for agent and skill building

  • AI Evaluation Services

  • Enterprise-wide Knowledge Graphs

This foundation gives developers and IT teams the infrastructure to build, deploy, and scale AI applications confidently.

5. Business Data Cloud Gets Smarter

SAP’s Business Data Cloud isn’t just for analytics anymore. It’s now fueling intelligent applications like:

  • People Intelligence (HR insights from SuccessFactors)

  • Spend Control Tower

  • Green Ledger for sustainability tracking

With connections to Google BigQuery, AWS, and Azure, your data is ready for intelligent automation at scale.

6. Developer-Centric AI Enhancements

If you’re building on SAP, you’re in for a treat:

  • Low-code AI agent development via Joule Studio

  • AI-powered ABAP tooling for ECC migration

  • Custom LLM integration in the Integration Suite

  • Marketplace availability via AWS and GCP

SAP’s message is clear: AI should be easy to build and run, not a black box.

7. Real-Time Intelligence with Perplexity AI

One of the most intriguing partnerships is with Perplexity AI, giving SAP users access to real-time, web-validated information — integrated directly into their business queries.

This means you’re no longer limited to internal data. Joule can now combine enterprise knowledge with trusted external content for complete, contextual answers.

Final Thoughts

SAP Sapphire 2025 marked a pivotal shift — from talking about AI to operationalizing it at scale. Whether you’re in tech, operations, or strategy, these announcements reflect one reality: AI is now core to SAP — and core to the future of enterprise transformation.

entry.title: Mastering Complex SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations
entry.content:
Welcome back to our new blog series,  our previous blog series  delved into the intricacies of dynamic sequential approval workflows.

In this two-part series, my colleague @Adwait_Fadnavis  and I will explore some very critical business workflow  requirements  in detail using SAP Build Process Automation. 

Throughout this blog series, we will delve into the following critical business requirements:

Part 1 - Current Blog :Mastering Complex SBPA Approvals : A Deep Dive into Wait Steps, Script Tasks, and API Integrations

Part 2 : Demonstration with Complete end to end testing 

We will demonstrate how to use various SAP Build Process Automation tools to solve real-time challenges effectively.

This blog post addresses this complex requirement with detailed step-by-step instructions. You'll learn how to ensure workflows advance smoothly, even with  approval condition utilizing various innovative latest features such as: Wait Step with API Triggering , Workflow Context update via API etc.

Business Context and Problem Statement

While working on multiple SAP Build Process Automation projects, we have faced situations where workflows only proceed if all departments or approvers approve them unanimously.

If any approver rejects the proposal, the entire workflow is rejected . This creates a need for a parallel approval process, adhering to an "all-or-nothing" requirement, which SAP's standard solutions do not support.

In a below sample procurement workflow, the request is created and submitted. Both the Department Manager and Finance Department must approve it simultaneously. If either rejects, the workflow is terminated.

If both approve, the request goes to the Executive for final approval. The Executive's decision determines whether the request is processed or terminated.

Dynamic Number of Parallel Approval
Technical Solutioning & Design

In this process, we will create two workflows using SAP Build Process Automation’s Low Code/No Code approach.

Let’s refer to these as Workflow A (main workflow) and Workflow B.

Workflow A( Main Workflow): This is the main workflow, triggered with all input parameters, responsible for the overall business process flow.

Workflow B(Secondary Workflow): This workflow handles the approval task. It receives the Approval ID, total number of levels, and current level. If the final approval is granted, it triggers a wait step API  in Workflow A to proceed to the next level. If more approvals are needed, it sends the Approval ID to the next level.

 
Technical Design Steps for Workflow A:
 
  1. Trigger Workflow: The workflow is initiated with input parameters.
  2. Decision Creation: A decision step is created to determine the number of approvals require. 

3. Script Task: This step determines the total number of approvals and the current approval level.

$.context.custom.doneapprovalcount = 0;
$.context.custom.currentcount = 0;
$.context.custom.subwfdefinationid = "Your Secondaray Workflow ID"; // replace with your secondary workflow id
$.context.custom.totalapprovalcount = $.context.decision_getAppprovers_1.Approvers.length;
$.context.custom.triggeredsubprocessids = [];
​
  • Condition Check: If the current level matches the total required approvals, A wait step will be created to wait for the completion. If not, Workflow B is triggered to initiate the approval task.

  • Trigger Workflow B: Workflow B sends the work item to the respective user for approval.
  • Wait Step API : This critical step waits for all parallel approvals to be completed. Once done, the dummy decision is triggered by Workflow B. This is very interesting and latest features
    1. Create a Wait Step with API as follows. After Deployment it will event will create the API End Point which will used to trigger from secondary workflow B .      
    2. Execution ID is the Parent Workflow ID.
    3. Upload the API specification and create the action for this
    4.  Also make sure to create the API key which will be used to trigger it from secondary workflow B.

Technical Design Steps for Workflow B  (Triggered via Workflow A)

  1. Trigger from Workflow A : Workflow B starts when Workflow A reaches a certain point to manage approval tasks separately and in parallel to the main workflow.

  2. Send Approval Task: The approval task is sent to the current level approver to obtain necessary approvals at each level before proceeding.
  3. On Approval: The system retrieves instance details and updates the approval count to keep track of completed approvals and update the workflow status.  
  4. sample code
$.context.custom.approvedcount = $.context.action_get_getV1WorkflowInstancesWorkflowInstanceIdContext_6.result.custom.doneapprovalcount + 1;
  • Check Count: The system checks if all required approvals are obtained:
    • If all approvals are done, the workflow proceeds to the next step.
    • If not all approvals are done This ensures the workflow only proceeds once all approvals are obtained
  •  Update Parent Workflow A Approval Action : increment the update count. created a custom action. If all the approvals not done, then update the approval count via custom action. (refer our previous blog how to create action for workflow API)   
  • Retrieve Task ID & Trigger Wait API trigger wait step ( API) in Workflow A to signal that the approval process is complete / Reject  and it can proceed.
    • Now come to most crucial part of the Development: Trigger the wait step via API
    • Created a custom action project  for the wait step api end point.
    • Here is the Input mapping for the API call. Needs to provide the API Key and Parent ID.
    • It will trigger the wait step in workflow A to approve / move forward the workflow . 
 
In the upcoming blog post - Demonstration with complete end to end testing  , @Adwait_Fadnavis  will delve into the complete end to end testing for these which is very critical to understand the whole development flow.
 
Stay tuned for a comprehensive guide that will enhance your understanding and streamline your Development  process.

Regards,

Mohit Bansal,

SAP Mentor. SAP BTP Solution Architect

entry.title: Multi-modal RAG Proof of Concept: facilitating tech support
entry.content:
Disclaimer

Please keep an eye on the current state of SAP’s Grounding service, as it will receive updates implementing Multi-modal RAG features in the future. For the extraction of structured data only, you might also want to consider using SAP’s Document Information Extraction service.

Introduction

As the applicability of generative AI in different use cases is being tested and researched every day at SAP, many new approaches are implemented to be proven possible and reliable. While Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) is less of a new topic in this context, its utility remains highly variable, depending on the data types that the respective documents contain.

This blog outlines how a multi-modal RAG approach was successfully implemented as part of a proof-of-concept (PoC) for one of SAP’s customers, therefore fulfilling the reoccurring customer need for an AI assistant with the ability to interpret image content. We will focus on how the multi-modal RAG works, as it’s leveraging several SAP services, just as custom-built approaches.

Business situation & challenge

To begin with, we will look at the business situation and the resulting challenges at hand. In this case, an insurance company faced the challenge of handling a high volume of repetitive requests from business users concerning various systems and applications, with differing levels of complexity and detail. The company operates an implementation of one of SAP’s standard LoB solutions, enhanced by its own custom extensions. These extensions are thoroughly documented, using text, graphics, and diagrams to convey key information. However, the IT support team continues to struggle with overload and availability issues, as users often submit questions directly rather than consulting the available manuals. Additionally, similar business requests are repeatedly submitted by different business users and handled separately by various IT team members. This fragmented approach leads to significant inefficiencies and contributes to the IT team’s overload. Looking at these challenges, we saw the potential for an AI solution to enhance the efficiency of business support and consulting.

Implemented solution

To realize this potential, we developed an AI-driven partner for instant support, relieving a lot of the IT team’s workload by answering said business requests.

As mentioned in the beginning of this blog, this project was executed as a PoC, exploring a solution that efficiently manages recurring business requests by leveraging AI capabilities. This involves a web application on the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), utilizing technologies such as the Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core and SAP HANA Cloud’s Vector Engine to provide enriched support content and timely responses, ultimately alleviating IT strain and enhancing service availability. Responses are based on the extension manuals, which include both text and images that need to be interpreted to generate reliable answers. While plain text and tables are easily retrievable and result in (...mostly ^^) reliable answers, pictures, diagrams and dashboards present a challenge when trying to generate document-based responses – this is where the multi-modal RAG comes into play. To clarify the scope of our solution, it should be stated that we did not implement functionality for detecting or processing tables, as tables were not part of the provided documents.

Technical Architecture

Before we dive into the workflow of our multi-modal RAG solution, let’s take a quick look at the Architecture of the web application which implements the RAG Reference Architecture on SAP Architecture Center.


The web application is built on SAP BTP, running on its Cloud Foundry Runtime, thereby ensuring scalability and managed infrastructure. We used the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) to develop the backend services and Use Case Logic, utilizing LLM Plugins, SDKs and the SAP Cloud SDK for AI which are important for our multi-modal RAG purposes. The CAP application accesses the Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core via Generative AI Hub SDK, harnessing Generative AI capabilities in a model-agnostic way. In our case, we use gpt-4o which acts as an agent and is one of two nodes in a simple langgraph, the other node being used to invoke our agent tools. Speaking of multiple tools here is not accurate though, as we exclusively invoke our multi-modal RAG as a tool for the agent to access. Having an agent only using a single tool might seem absurd but it turns out that for some rather complex questions, the agent will still break things down into multiple invocations of the same tool (with different queries) and then combine the answers together in a final step. – we will go into the further details of that when talking about the multi-modal RAG approach in a moment. Frontend wise, UI5 Web Components was used to build the User Interface, which we deploy at a HTML5 App Repo.

Multi-modal RAG

Now that we have outlined the overall application architecture, let’s get to the interesting part! Keep in mind that one of the main challenges we are faced with is interpreting the images contained in our documents to retrieve all the relevant information when necessary.

When designing a multi-modal RAG pipeline, one must evaluate and choose among several approaches. As shown in this GitHub Repository published by LangChain, we saw three possible options on how to build our RAG pipeline. While the LangChain documentation provides a general overview of how to implement this approach, we will delve deeper into the specifics of our solution to highlight technical details and differences to the LangChain approach:



As you can see, we do a lot of preprocessing for the documents before putting them in our database to fetch them at runtime. Naturally, we will first take a look at what’s happening at design time.

First, all the images contained in the pdfs are extracted using the python fitz library. The images are then fed to the LLM, which is instructed to generate descriptions of said images (as explained earlier, the LLM access happens via Generative AI Hub SDK). In a subsequent step, the images in the documents are replaced with their generated description and a reference to the image itself. Ultimately, the plain text - containing image descriptions and references – is chunked with LangChain’s semantic chunker and embedded using text-embedding-ada-002, which is consumed via Generative AI Hub SDK. Those embeddings are stored together with the original text and images in HANA Cloud’s Vector storage.

At runtime, every user query is embedded (again, using text-embedding-ada002). The Vector Engine performs a similarity search on the stored document embeddings, compares them to the embedded user query and picks the ten most similar chunks, just as the next chunk in front of and behind each of them. Since LLMs have a limit on the number of images they can accept as input, we must overcome this limitation when the context to be provided to the LLM includes more images than supported. We do so by passing in image descriptions for the extra images (coming from chunks with lesser relevance) instead of their actual image data. As depicted in the multi-modal RAG diagram above, the stored original text for each chunk is then, together with all the base64-encoded image data and potential image descriptions, given to the LLM for it to generate an answer. That way we can ensure that the LLM includes relevant information contained in the images just as reliably as if we retrieved text only. In other words: the LLM doesn't usually rely on image descriptions as its main source of information. That only tends to happen when the number of images exceeds the model’s processing limits. Typically, the input includes both the stored text and base64-encoded images within each chunk. 

Conclusion

We hope that this blog has given you a better understanding of how a custom-built multi-modal RAG application can look like. With our PoC we aim to take a step towards increased AI utility, exploring and enhancing existing techniques of combined text and image retrieval to set ground for future projects and upcoming SAP services. Implementing this solution enables users to interact with complex, document-based content in a natural way by combining text and visual information to generate context-aware, AI-powered answers that go beyond traditional RAG usage.

Looking forward to future research on new ways of implementing and enhancing multi-modal RAG, we invite you to ask questions and discuss on this topic in the comment section of this blog. Glad we got you hooked until the end! 😉

Finally, a big thank you to the entire team – @adi_pleyer, @kay, Vikas Thimmiaha, @Jackson7, @RobinP, @GerdBuchmueller,   @andriysobolsap, @g_kevorkian  and @ababalau - for your outstanding work and collaboration throughout this PoC.

entry.title: “The Unfiltered Truth About AI in SAP SuccessFactors: Insights and Realities
entry.content:
SAP SuccessFactors continues to embed AI capabilities across its key modules- Performance & Goals Management, Succession & Development Planning, and Talent Intelligence Hub, aiming to improve HR efficiency and decision-making. However, alongside these promising functionalities, real-world usage reveals notable challenges and limitations HR leaders must consider.

Note: Based on my expertise, this blog mentions AI functionalities in only a few SAP SuccessFactors modules—PMGM, SPCDP, and TIH.

AI in Performance & Goals Management (PMGM): Efficiency Meets Alignment

The latest AI-driven innovation in PMGM includes generative AI that helps draft personalized, aligned employee goals quickly, reducing administrative workload. Additionally, AI analyzes continuous feedback and performance data to provide managers with insights into employee trends and development needs.

The Reality Check: PMGM's AI Goal Creation

  • Week 1: Users are amazed by the speed

  • Week 2: Managers notice that AI-generated goals sound similar across teams; goals feel “robotic.”

  • Week 3:  Few AI-created goals are technically correct but practically purposeless, and most goals do not align with organizational strategy. As a result, Managers and HR spend time editing AI-generated goals instead of creating them

The Consultant’s Fix

AI-generated goals often require human review to ensure relevance and alignment with team dynamics. Overreliance on AI can lead to generic or misaligned objectives that fail to motivate employees. Use AI as your first draft, not your final answer. Think of it as having a very efficient intern who still needs supervision.

Succession & Development Planning (SPCDP): Data-Driven Yet Human-Centric

AI in SPCDP supports data-driven succession decisions by assessing potential successors' skills, experience, and readiness. It also recommends personalized career development paths and learning opportunities tailored to individual skill gaps.

The Reality Check

AI confidently recommends a high-performing individual contributor for a leadership role, completely missing the fact that this person had zero interest in management. The AI saw the skills match but it missed the human factor.

The Three Questions AI Can’t Answer (Yet)

  1. Does this person actually want the role? AI sees potential, not passion

  2. How will they handle the pressure? Performance under stress isn’t in the algorithm

  3. Do they fit the team culture? Soft skills remain frustratingly soft for AI.

While AI provides objective successor ratings and development suggestions, these outputs depend heavily on data quality and contextual interpretation by HR professionals. AI recommendations can miss cultural fit or individual aspirations if treated as prescriptive rather than advisory. Organizations must balance AI insights with human judgment to avoid rigid or ineffective succession plans.

The Consultant’s Fix

Use AI insights as your starting point for conversations, not your end point for decisions. The suggestions should guide, but not replace, human decisions. Career insights work better for junior roles than senior positions. Career insights help plan learning paths, but they must align with company culture and employee goals to be effective.

Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH): Precision in Skills Management

TIH’s AI now focuses on recent job roles to keep skills data accurate. It recommends learning based on skill levels and improves team visibility for managers. AI-driven learning suggestions help employees focus their development. Workflow updates add control over skill approvals, helping maintain clean data. This holistic view, powered by AI, helps organizations not only fill current roles but also anticipate future workforce trends and succession risks.

The Reality Check

TIH’s AI is like having a very enthusiastic research assistant who finds exactly what you asked for, even when it’s not what you need.

For TIH, the foundational requirement for clean, structured data is a major barrier. Many organizations find their HR data inconsistent or disconnected, limiting AI effectiveness. Without significant data cleanup, AI-driven insights in TIH may be inaccurate or misleading.

  • AI extracts every possible skill from job descriptions, creating overly large skill inventories that are difficult to manage.

  • AI suggests learning content for every skill gap, regardless of priority or relevance.

The Consultant’s Fix

  • Skills extraction works best for technical roles with clear competency requirements.

  • Learning recommendations are most effective for certification-based skills.

  • Ethical concerns around AI bias and transparency require ongoing governance and monitoring to maintain trust.

Strategic Takeaways for HR Leaders

  • Use AI to automate tasks, but always apply human judgment.

  • Keep data clean and governed for reliable AI results.

  • Set clear, realistic goals for AI adoption.

Conclusion

AI in HR isn’t about replacing human judgment; it’s about giving humans better data to make judgment calls. When you approach it that way, the technology becomes genuinely helpful rather than frustratingly inaccurate.

The future of HR technology isn’t about perfect AI—it’s about perfectly integrated AI that knows its place in human-centered processes.

If you want to explore how to balance AI and human insight in your HR processes, feel free to reach out for guidance.

Thank you for taking the time to read.

You are welcome to express your views and ask any queries in the comment section of this blog. I would be pleased to impart my knowledge to you.  Share this blog with your colleagues.

Additional Blogs

If you are planning a  Talent Intelligence Hub implementation, this blog has all the practical insights I've gained from actually deploying TIH in real client environments - the stuff that matters when you're in the middle of an implementation and need straight answers. TIH Implementation: Key Learnings from Client Projects 

If you are a Fresher and looking to specialize in SuccessFactors, check out my blog - Guide to Mastering SuccessFactors Consulting. You will find valuable insights and practical tips to gain expertise and establish yourself as an expert in the industry.

If you are planning an SAP SuccessFactors implementation, check out my blog - Prep Guide for a Flawless SAP SuccessFactors Implementation. This expert guide offers critical insights for a flawless project.

entry.title: Shaping the Future of Predictive Insights with Tabular AI and the SAP Foundational Model
entry.content:
Abstract

At SAP Sapphire, we unveiled a major milestone in our ongoing mission to simplify and elevate AI capabilities for our customers: Tabular AI. This groundbreaking initiative consolidates all of SAP’s existing AI services for structured tabular business data into a single, unified offering within SAP’s Generative AI Hub. Scheduled for general availability in the second half of 2025, tabular AI will streamline integration, enhance accessibility, and dramatically reduce complexity for developers and business users alike.

Beyond unification, tabular AI is designed as a launchpad for rapid innovation—setting the stage for next-generation capabilities like the SAP Foundation Model. Initially, these foundation model features will be available for embedded use cases, with a vision to expand to custom scenarios in the future, giving customers even greater flexibility.

If you’re new to the SAP Foundation Model we encourage you to explore our dedicated blog post and the on-demand SAP TechEd session for a comprehensive introduction. These resources provide valuable context on how foundational AI technologies are reshaping business applications.

Tabular AI underscores SAP’s commitment to democratizing AI and empowering every customer to unlock value from their data. Discover more in the full blog post and get ready for the future of enterprise AI.

 

The Challenge

Let’s start by facing the current reality. Business processes in enterprises heavily rely on structured tabular data. When it comes to creating predictive insights from this data, our landscape today is fragmented and siloed. While SAP has developed robust AI services tailored for structured tabular data, such as Data Attribute Recommendation for classification and regression scenarios, Personalized Recommendations delivering tailored user experiences and relevant content to support diverse business objectives and recommendation scenarios., and embedded matching scenarios (like Cash Application), each solving specific challenges effectively, these services would benefit by harmonizing into a comprehensive, unified solution for customers.

This structure has evolved naturally over time, resulting in each AI service possessing its distinct architecture and workflow. While these services are functional, SAP is actively enhancing them to streamline integration and simplify adoption for application developers. These ongoing improvements also pave the way for more rapid and seamless incorporation of cutting-edge innovations, such as the SAP Foundation Model, across our AI Services landscape.

We are excited to announce the introduction of tabular AI, a significant step forward in advancing our AI capabilities. Tabular AI will serve two key objectives: first, to unify our existing AI services tailored for structured tabular data into a single, integrated platform, and second, to expedite the integration of groundbreaking AI research, particularly in the realm of generative AI, into our products. This strategic move is aimed at not only simplifying the technological landscape but also at propelling our offerings to the forefront of AI innovation.

 

Unification

Tabular AI will unify all existing AI service offerings for structured tabular data under the umbrella of SAP’s Generative AI Hub, streamlining integration, lifecycle management, and accelerating implementation timelines. This comprehensive approach will democratize predictive AI capabilities, making them more accessible and easier to maintain. By doing so, business developers will be better equipped to effectively leverage these tools within their custom AI applications or embedded AI scenarios. As a result, business developers will be better equipped to leverage these tools in custom AI applications and embedded AI scenarios. For application developers, this unification means a simpler integration process, with a single service plan and service key required for their applications.

With this transformative change, the focus shifts from selecting a suitable AI solution for an application to concentrating directly on the desired AI functionality - be it classification, regression, matching, recommendation, or other capabilities that may emerge in the future. Notably, the inclusion of the matching capability represents a significant enhancement, as this functionality was not previously available through an existing AI service offering.

Moving forward, all these functionalities will be accessible through a unified entry point - the AI API. This consolidation simplifies the user experience and expedites the deployment of advanced AI capabilities, allowing developers to seamlessly integrate and apply these functionalities across various applications more efficiently without the challenges of managing multiple technologies or models. By eliminating barriers related to the technology stack and model selection, developers can more effectively concentrate on utilizing the precise functionality needed to add value in their specific contexts, thereby driving innovative use of AI across industries.

However, tabular AI isn't just about simplifying the developer's experience; it also paves the way for seamless integration of future innovations. A prominent example is the SAP Foundation Model, leading us into the discussion of innovation.

 

Innovation

With tabular AI in place, we are seizing the opportunity to stay at the forefront of innovation. By unifying our architecture and workflow, Tabular AI enables the seamless integration of cutting-edge technologies and native adoption of new advancements.

At launch, tabular AI will incorporate advanced AI models designed to deliver unprecedented levels of predictive insight and flexibility. Leveraging large-scale business data, these models will unlock a wealth of new use cases and transform the way users interact with our solutions.

A key feature is the SAP Foundation Model, a table-native Transformer that brings adaptive, in-context learning to tabular AI. Unlike traditional models that require repeated training for each use case, the SAP Foundation Model provides on-the-fly predictions for individual records based on provided examples. This adaptability allows the model to respond dynamically to changing data without retraining, substantially simplifying the entire machine learning lifecycle and reducing operational complexity.

Customers will benefit from increased intelligence and automation in embedded scenarios, enabling faster, more accurate decision-making. Over time, this technology will supercharge a broad range of use cases across the SAP portfolio - streamlining business processes, increasing efficiency, and reducing manual effort.

Initially, this capability will support embedded classification and regression use cases within SAP applications. This focused rollout ensures high reliability while setting the stage for expanding to broader custom scenarios in the future.

 

What's in for Me

Looking ahead to 2025, our vision is to make AI for structured data both simpler and more powerful for everyone using SAP. With the upcoming launch of tabular AI as a flagship service within SAP’s Generative AI Hub, we are unifying and streamlining all our existing capabilities by consolidating features from Data Attribute Recommendation and Personalized Recommendation and introducing matching as a native capability. Tabular AI will serve as your one-stop shop for all predictive tasks involving structured business data, providing you with a seamless and integrated user experience.

We are also taking a significant step forward by embedding cutting-edge technology: Tabular AI will feature in-context learning powered by the SAP Foundation Model. This enables highly adaptive, context-aware predictions based on real-time examples—without requiring traditional, exhaustive retraining. As your business data evolves, the model dynamically adapts, delivering relevant predictions and keeping pace with changing requirements

For the initial release of those advanced capabilities powered by the SAP Foundation Model, we are prioritizing embedded scenarios such as classification and regression tasks deeply integrated within SAP applications. By focusing on well-established use cases with proven business value, we can rigorously test and refine in-context learning, ensuring maximum reliability and robustness. This strategy will help us build a strong foundation for expanding advanced capabilities to broader and more customized scenarios in the future.

We are aiming to make tabular AI generally available in the second half of 2025.

 

Next Steps on our Journey

All of this is, however, just the beginning. Looking ahead, we anticipate a transformational leap in how advanced AI models generate insights from linked business data. Rather than requiring each tabular AI scenario to be explicitly modeled at design time, we envision a future where users can easily obtain both simple and sophisticated insights through flexible, ad-hoc predictions that accommodate real-time data changes, extensions, user interactions, and feedback. This approach will ensure the most accurate and effective insights from your business data.

These developments will also pave the way for the next generation of highly autonomous, agentic AI scenarios. Unlike today’s narrow AI models, future scenarios will support a broader range of execution and will benefit from precisely grounded insights, leveraging the foundation of structured tabular data for greater accuracy and reliability.

In effect, we expect nothing less than a democratization of AI in the structured tabular space, where a massive growth of capabilities is fueled by empowering application developers and end users alike to generate targeted AI insights as easily and swiftly as writing prompts for textual tasks performed by an LLM. As these capabilities advance, generating insights with AI will become standard practice rather than an exception - until, eventually, almost every process will be AI-powered, with only a few remaining untouched.

As part of this evolution, we will begin to phase out and deprecate our legacy AI services. This move will fully realize the unification vision: A single, universal entry point for all AI capabilities supporting structured business data. Unifying our services brings several strategic benefits:

  • Accelerated innovation: Features and updates reach you faster.
  • Streamlined integration: New advancements can be incorporated seamlessly into the existing portfolio.
  • Reduced total cost of ownership: Consolidating offerings minimizes maintenance overhead, lowering costs and increasing overall value.

For customers currently leveraging Data Attribute Recommendation or Personalized Recommendation, rest assured that there is no immediate action required. Our top priority is to ensure your business processes continue uninterrupted. We’ll reach out proactively to facilitate a smooth transition to tabular AI and to support you every step of the way.

 

Conclusion

Tabular AI marks a significant leap towards simplifying and unifying AI for structured business data at SAP. By consolidating existing AI services and introducing advanced AI capabilities like in-context learning through the SAP Foundation Model, we’re making predictive AI more powerful, accessible, and future-ready.

While the initial focus is on embedded use cases, our long-term vision is a flexible, unified offering that adapts to evolving business needs and fosters innovation at scale. This transformation is more than a technical evolution - it’s an invitation to reimagine what’s possible with your data. As we move towards a future where AI-powered insights become omnipresent, SAP remains committed to supporting your journey every step of the way.

We look forward to sharing more as tabular AI evolves. Your input will be vital as we shape this next chapter - so stay connected and be part of the journey.

Stay tuned for more updates!

entry.title: Using Trading Partner Management with AI
entry.content:
Extending AI Capabilities: Diving Deeper with the MCP Trading Partner Management Server

Following up on my previous article, "Using Integration Suite with the Power of AI," where I showcased how to extend Integration Suite development with AI and the ModelContextProtocol (MCP), I'm excited to introduce a specialized enhancement: the **MCP Trading Partner Management (TPM) Server**.

While the initial MCP Integration Suite Server provides broad tools for general CPI functions like Integration Flows and Message Mappings, many enterprise integration scenarios heavily rely on managing B2B relationships. This new server is purpose-built to give AI chat clients direct access to and control over the rich capabilities of SAP Integration Suite's Trading Partner Management. It makes sense to install both servers together to have access to both tools combined.

 

What Can You Do With It? A Comprehensive Toolset

The MCP Trading Partner Management Server empowers AI assistants with a wide array of tools to manage your B2B integration aspects. Here's an overview of its core capabilities:

  • Trading Partner Management: Create, retrieve, and manage trading partners, their systems, identifiers, communication channels, and even signature verification configurations.
  • Agreement Management: Work with B2B agreements, including creation from templates, retrieving details, and managing their associated technical B2B scenarios and deployments.
  • Message Implementation Guideline (MIG) Management: Access and manipulate MIGs, including inspecting nodes and fields, applying proposals, and creating new MIG drafts.
  • Mapping Guideline (MAG) Management: Create mapping guidelines and test them with example data
  • Monitoring: Search for interchanges, retrieve payload data, download specific payloads, and access error details for TPM message monitoring.
  • Other Utilities: Get details on type systems, messages within them, create custom messages, and retrieve master data like business process roles, countries, and product classifications.

 

Setup and Configuration

As with the previous server, I highly recommend using this tool with Cline, the VSCode extension, or any other MCP-compatible client.

This server requires **Java (version 17 or higher)** and **Gradle (version 8 or higher)** to be installed on your machine. Once you have these prerequisites, get started by cloning the project and building it:

git clone https://github.com/1nbuc/mcp-is-tpm.git
cd mcp-is-tpm
./gradlew build

Next, you'll need to add the MCP Trading Partner Management Server to your AI Client's MCP configuration. This is typically done alongside your existing `mcp-is` configuration to provide the full spectrum of tools. The `env` variables below should be configured with your SAP Integration Suite URL and user credentials.

Note on Credentials: If your S or P user is associated with a Universal ID, ensure you provide your Universal ID password and email (`CPI_UNIVERSAL_MAIL`). If you have a standalone S-User, simply omit the `CPI_UNIVERSAL_MAIL` variable.

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "mcp-is": {
      "command": "node",
      "args": [
        "<project path for mcp-integration-suite>/dist/index.js"
      ],
      "autoApprove": []
    },
    "mcp-is-tpm": {
      "command": "java",
      "args": [
        "-Dlogging.pattern.console=",
        "-Dspring.main.web-application-type=none",
        "-Dspring.ai.mcp.server.stdio=true",
        "-jar",
        "<project path for mcp-is-tpm>/app/build/libs/app-0.0.1-SNAPSHOT.jar"
      ],
      "autoApprove": [],
      "env": {
        "CPI_URL": "https://your.cpi.url.hana.ondemand.com",
        "CPI_USER": "S001234567",
        "CPI_PASSWORD": "myPass123",
        "CPI_UNIVERSAL_MAIL": "mail@company.de"
      }
    }
  }
}

Remember to replace `<project path for mcp-integration-suite>` and `<project path for mcp-is-tpm>` with the actual local paths to your cloned repositories.

For optimal interaction and to guide the AI effectively, I highly recommend starting each chat session with a custom prompt, similar to the approach outlined in my previous blog post.

 

What Can You Actually Do With It? (Conceptual Examples)

With the comprehensive toolset provided by the MCP Trading Partner Management Server, you can instruct your AI assistant to handle intricate TPM tasks. Here are a few conceptual examples:

Example 1: Create new Partners and Communication with them

You are a fishing shop with SAP ERP and SAP Integration suite
Here is a list of trading partners, look if they exist already otherwise create them.
Rod Supplier rody
Fishermans port LLC

Here is a list of transactions I do with partners. For every partnertransaction find a suitable Agreement template and create an agreement based on it.
All partners use AS2. If there is no fitting System with communication please create it. Deploy the agreements afterwards
Send orders D01B to rody
Receive D01B invoices from rody
Send TRADACOMS invoices to fishermans port

This could also be done if a list of 100+ User is provided e.g. if you would have an excel sheet with some partners and want to save time by not having to click create such many times.

 

Example 2: Analyzing an Existing Trading Partner Configuration

"Get details about Partner XY and list all their configured systems and communication channels."

This is also usefull for summerizing or finding stuff.

"Find all Partners that use a SOAP Channel"

Example 3: Creating a New MIG for an Inbound PO

"Create a new Message Implementation Guideline for an inbound Purchase Order (PO) based on the EDIFACT D.96A standard. Then, get the proposal and select all fields which have over 50% probability."

This highlights the ability to automate the creation of structured message guidelines, which are foundational for B2B document exchange.

Example 4: Troubleshooting an Inbound B2B Message

"Search for all interchanges with errors in the last day from partner 'XYSolutions'. For the latest error message, get the interchange payloads and identify the root cause from the last error details."

This scenario leverages the monitoring tools to quickly pinpoint and diagnose issues in B2B message processing.

 

 

If you are interested do not hesitate to check out the project on github for more details. I look forward to hearing your thoughts and experiences in the comments, also let me know if you have any features or promps you would like to see! Also thanks to figaf for providing an API for lots of TPM Capabilities.

entry.title: Using the SAP Cloud Javascript SDK for AI
entry.content:
Using the SAP Cloud Javascript SDK for AI

Introduction

In this blog, We will build a Node.js Service with authenticaton that Talks to SAP Generative AI Hub. We’ll spin up a tiny Express server, protect it with XSUAA, call an OpenAI model (gpt-4o-mini) deployed in the Generative AI Hub, and push the whole thing to Cloud Foundry.

Source code is ~70 lines; everything else is service wiring.

Table of Contents

  1. Prerequisites
  1. Step 1 — Destination services
  1. Step 2 — Create the XSUAA instance
  1. Step 3 — Scaffold the Node project
  1. Step 4 — Deploy to BTP
  1. Step 5 — Test with Postman
  1. Useful Links

1 · Prerequisites

  • BTP sub-account (any region)
  • Generative AI Hub enabled in BTP Cockpit
  • Node.js ≥ 18 & cf CLI v8 - https://nodejs.org
  • Postman - https://www.postman.com/
  • VSCode - https://code.visualstudio.com/
  • AI Core Instance & Service Key created from BTP

2 · Step 1 — Create Destination Service

Creation of a Destination Service is needed as we will be using it to connect to our GenAI hub instance. There is a way to define custom destination programatically mentioned here.

https://sap.github.io/cloud-sdk/docs/js/features/connectivity/destinations#register-destination

However from my testing I just couldn’t got it to connect to my genai instance. So I will be creating a destination following the documentation

https://sap.github.io/ai-sdk/docs/js/connecting-to-ai-core

  1. Create the Destination Service

    Go to the Instances and Subscriptions and click the create button to the right

Select the Destination Service and name it whatever you like

Click on the newly created Destination Service Instance and create a Service Key for it

And then click the 3 dots up on the right corner and go to option View Dashboard here we will be creating a destination. Create a HTTP destination and select Authentication type as “OAuth2ClientCredentials” paste-in the values you have beforehand from the AI Core Service service key.

Important!

Make sure to add /oauht/token to the end of your Token Service URL if there is none.

Click Check Connection. It will give a message;

✅Connection to "my-aicore" established. Response returned: "404: Not Found”.

This is fine as we are not sending a request to the destination yet.

3 · Step 2 — Create XSUAA Service and Service Key

Just like the steps we did when creating our Destination Service create an Authorization and Trust Management (XSUAA) service instance and then create a service key for it.

Only thing to pay attention is to select plan “broker” when creating the service

Then just create the service keys for this service aswell.

4 · Step 3 — Scaffold the Node project

mkdir genai-node && cd genai-node
npm init -y
npm i express -ai-sdk/foundation-models
npm i cfenv /xssec
npm i -D typescript rimraf
npm i -D @types/express @types/cfenv to the
npx tsc --init --outDir dist --rootDir src \
 --target es2022 --module es2022 \
 --moduleResolution node --esModuleInterop tru
mkdir src
touch .cfignore #here put the paths of the files you don't want to deploy to BTP
⚠️TypeScript typings & Express version
  • This tutorial uses express@5.1 (bundles its own .d.ts files).

    Do not install @types/express with Express 5 – VS Code will show

    “Duplicate identifier / Cannot redeclare …” errors because two sets of
    typings clash.

  • If you decide to downgrade to express@4.x, then you must add

    npm i -D @types/express so the compiler can find the declarations.

In both cases you can safely install the helpers below:

# always safe
npm i -D @types/node @types/cfenv

They silence any remaining red squiggles without affecting runtime.

Complete tsconfig.json

{
 "compilerOptions": {
 "target": "es2022",
 "module": "es2022",
 "moduleResolution": "node",
 "rootDir": "src",
 "outDir": "dist",
 "esModuleInterop": true,
 "allowSyntheticDefaultImports": true,
 "skipLibCheck": true // turns off deep type-checking in node_modules
 },
 "include": ["src/**/*.ts", "*.ts"]
}

Complete package.json

{
 "name": "genai-node",
 "version": "1.0.0",
 "type": "module",
 "scripts": {
 "build": "rimraf dist && tsc",
 "start": "npm run build && node dist/server.js"
 },
 "dependencies": {
 "@sap-ai-sdk/ai-api": "^1.15.0",
 "@sap-ai-sdk/foundation-models": "^1.15.0",
 "@sap-ai-sdk/langchain": "^1.15.0",
 "@sap-ai-sdk/orchestration": "^1.15.0",
 "@sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity": "^4.0.2",
 "@sap/xssec": "^4.8.0",
 "cfenv": "^1.2.4",
 "dotenv": "^16.5.0",
 "express": "^5.1.0"
 },
 "devDependencies": {
 "rimraf": "^6.0.1",
 "ts-node": "^10.9.2",
 "tsx": "^4.20.3",
 "typescript": "^5.8.3"
 }
}

We compile on CF during npm start; the buildpack installs devDeps by default, so no extra steps required.

Create src/server.ts:

import express, { Request, Response, NextFunction } from 'express';
import { AzureOpenAiChatClient } from '@sap-ai-sdk/foundation-models';
import xssec from '@sap/xssec';
import cfenv from 'cfenv';
const app = express();
const port = process.env.PORT || 3000;
const XSUAA_SERVICE_NAME = process.env.XSUAA_SERVICE_NAME;
const appEnv = cfenv.getAppEnv();
const xsuaaService = appEnv.getService(XSUAA_SERVICE_NAME as any);
if (!xsuaaService) {
 throw new Error(`XSUAA service "${XSUAA_SERVICE_NAME}" not bound!`);
}
const uaaCreds = xsuaaService.credentials;
function verifyJwt(req: Request, _res: Response, next: NextFunction) {
 const auth = req.headers.authorization;
 if (!auth?.startsWith('Bearer ')) {
 return _res.status(403).send('Missing bearer token');
 }
 const token = auth.slice(7);
 xssec.createSecurityContext(token, uaaCreds)
 .then(() => next())
.catch((e: any) => {
 console.error('JWT rejected →', e.innerError ?? e.message ?? e);
 _res.status(403).send(String(e.innerError?.message ?? e.message));
});
}
const chat = new AzureOpenAiChatClient(
 {
 modelName: 'gpt-4o-mini' ,
 resourceGroup: 'your-resource-group'
 },
 {
 destinationName: 'my-aicore'
 }
);
app.post('/chat', verifyJwt express.json(), async (req, res) => {
 const userMsg = String(req.body.message ?? '');
 try {
 const resp = await chat.run({
 messages: [{ role: 'user', content: userMsg }]
 });
 res.json({ answer: resp.getContent() });
 } catch (e: any) {
 console.error(e);
 res.status(500).json({ error: e?.message ?? 'server error' });
 }
});
app.listen(port, () => console.log('⇢ listening on', port));

5 · Step 4 — Deploy to BTP

manifest.yaml

---
applications:
 - name: genai-node
 buildpack: nodejs_buildpack
 command: npm start
 memory: 256M
 env:
 XSUAA_SERVICE_NAME: xsuaa-blog #Name of your service
 services:
 - destination-service
 - xsuaa-blog

Push the codebase to the CloudFoundry and check if it is running

cf push
cf logs genai-node --recent

5 · Step 6—Test with Postman

After you deploy the application click on it to get the custom link to the app.

  • Open up Postman and write your request with your endpoint
  • Go to the Authorization tab → Select OAuth 2.0
  • Enter credentials

  • Scroll down to the “Get New Access Token” and then “Use Token”.

Now you are good to send the request and get a result

{
 "answer": "Hello! How can I assist you today?"
}

7 · Useful Links

  • https://www.sap.com/events/teched/virtual/flow/sap/te24/catalog/page/catalog/session/1722557682293001fTqe
  • https://github.com/SAP-samples/teched2024-AI180
  • https://sap.github.io/ai-sdk/docs/js/connecting-to-ai-core
  • https://sap.github.io/cloud-sdk/docs/js/tutorials/getting-started/introduction

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) - Generate ESG Reports With AI Application
entry.content:
SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) has introduced an out-of-the-box functionality, Generate ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) reports with AI application. With the Generate ESG Reports with AI app, the ESG reporting process is automated across the selected periods. It uses the ESG data that has already been imported into SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) and creates the reports based on the imported data. The AI generated reports are available to download in the .pdf format.

In this blog, I will outline how to define the content for custom templates based on set of facts, i.e.,  available metrics or reference facts, and how to generate ESG reports by leveraging AI.

Mini Note:

If you want to understand the nitty-gritty of SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) out-of-the-box functionalities and its Integration with SAP EHSM-EM (Emission Management), check-out my blog posts listed below.

  1. European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) 
  2. SAP Sustainability Control Tower-Import Greenhouse Gas Emissions from SAP EHS Environment Management 
  3. Addendum to SAP Sustainability Control Tower-Import Greenhouse Gas Emissions from SAP EHSM-EM 
  4. SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) Metric Management-Basic Custom Metric & Standard Custom Metric 
  5. Exporting and Importing Custom Objects and CPE Packages in SAP Sustainability Control Tower 
  6. Managing Qualitative Metrics in SAP Sustainability Control Tower(SCT) for ESRS and BRSR Framework 
  7. SAP S/4HANA EHS : Environment Management (Emissions Management) – Part:1 (Master Data Entities) 
  8. SAP S/4HANA EHS : Environment Management (Emissions Management) – Part:2 (Identifying & Preparing Compliance Requirement) 
  9. SAP S/4HANA EHS : Environment Management (Emissions Management) – Part:3 (Compliance Scenario Activities) 

 

Let us get started...why wait?...

Generate ESG Reports With AI Application

 

Let us take look at the "Prerequisites" before we dive in

  1. ESG specific data must have been imported into SAP Sustainability Control Tower (SCT)
